Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: The effect of ozone short-term exposure on flow-mediated dilation: Using data before and after COVID-19 lockdown in Shanghai.

AbstractText: Short-term ambient ozone exposure has been shown to have an adverse impact on endothelial function, contributing to major cardiovascular diseases and premature death. However, only limited studies have focused on the impact of short-term ozone exposure on Flow-mediated Dilation (FMD), and their results have been inconsistent. The current study aims to explore the relationship between short-term ambient ozone exposure and FMD. In addition, the study aims to investigate how lockdown measures for COVID-19 may influence ozone concentration in the atmosphere.

Participants were recruited from a hospital in Shanghai from December 2020 to August 2022. Individuals' ozone exposure was determined using residential addresses. A distributed lag nonlinear model was adopted to assess the exposure-response relationship between short-term ozone exposure and FMD. A comparison was made between ambient ozone concentration and FMD data collected before and after Shanghai's lockdown in 2022.

When ozone concentration was between 150 and 200 μg/m<sup>3</sup>, there was a significant reduction in FMD with a 2-day lag. Elderly individuals (age ≥ 65), females, non-drinkers, and non-smokers were found to be more susceptible to high concentrations of ozone exposure. The lockdown did elevate ambient ozone concentration compared to the same period previously.

This study proposes that an ambient ozone concentration of 150-200 μg/m<sup>3</sup> is harmful to endothelial function, and that a reduction in human activity during lockdown increased the concentration, which in turn reduced FMD. However, the underlying mechanism requires further research.
